B00008PW3Q|3.0|I was among many who welcomed the release of \\"Say You Will\\", and purchased it almost automatically.  I don't admit to being the biggest Fleetwood Mac fan, but do like much of their music.  Coming off of their live reunion \\"The Dance\\", it seemed like the spark was still there to create some good music.  I also didn't worry about the departure of Christine McVie, though her contributions to the group were subtly immense.  However, after the first several listens, I find myself grasping at what this disc is about and just how well it ranks in their catalog - not to mention the music market as a whole. <br />On the very first listen, I found myself very surprised - almost dumbstruck.  The lead track seemed to have elements of that classic Fleetwood Mac sound, but it was somehow different.  Then came the Lindsay Buckingham-penned track \\"Edward Murrow Spinning In His Grave\\".  My jaw nearly hit the floor, and not in a good way.  I noted that the next track would be a Stevie Nicks composition, \\"Illume\\".  So, being a fan of her music, I figured this song would level things out.  I was wrong.  Though not as bad as the preceding track, it wasn't great either.  My reaction to the next three tracks were pretty much the same, save for \\"Miranda\\", which - while a little \\"out there\\" - was fairly enjoyable. <br />Finally I hit the title track, another Nicks composition.  Now it seemed like things had returned to some semblance of \\"normalcy\\".  The following track, \\"Peacekeeper\\", is also a good track (with the minor criticism of having a chorus that sounds way too much like Paul Simon's \\"Kodachrome\\").  The remainder of the CD, then, was very pleasant and eminently more enjoyable.  They were incorporating new elements in their songs, but they were deeply rooted in that \\"classic\\" Fleetwood Mac sound that fans through the years have enjoyed. <br />Am I suggesting thus far that they had to reproduce \\"Rumours\\" here?  Hardly.  What I am suggesting is that I appreciate their willingness to experiment a little and sound \\"fresh\\" in 2003.  However, I don't think you mess with the basic roots of what made you successful in the first place.  That's the difficulty with listening to this CD; in the second half, they accomplished this. It's just that first half that is so wildly bizarre.<br />Therein lies the problem with \\"Say You Will\\", and I think it partly stems from the fact that Lindsay Buckingham - and perhaps Stevie Nicks to some extent - had so much influence on this disc that it comes off as sounding more like one of their solo albums with the Fleetwood Mac label attached.  I can only guess that Buckingham as producer was influenced by his work on \\"Tusk\\" when he set out on this project.  Reviewers preceding me have already drawn that comparison, except that I think \\"Tusk\\" was an easier listen.  \\"Say You Will\\" is in a completely different orbit.  <br />One of my immediate pet peeves on this disc's production was the incorporation of so much synthesized pop/R&B backbeats into the songs - particularly on that first half.  When you have arguably one of the greatest rock percussionists of all time in Mick Fleetwood and one of the better bassists in John McVie, why do you drown them out amidst a \\"canned\\" beat?  It's almost the equivalent of going to watch Eric Clapton, but hearing the guitar work of some lousy, two-bit schmoe working on a street corner.  At any rate, I think this is also why I was so pleased with the second half of this disc, because the Fleetwood-McVie tandem were finally allowed to show through, exposing some great work that demonstrates they still haven't lost their talents. <br />Would the presence of Christine McVie have evened this work out?  Hard to say.  As I noted above, she was very important to the group's success, but it seemed like they could go on without her.  Besides, she did contribute to some of these tracks; if you listen hard enough, you can pick them up.  <br />I think in the end, though, Buckingham was given so much control of this effort as much to make sure it would truly be a real Fleetwood Mac effort - not the version that existed after he quit in the late-80's.  The result is more a Buckingham-Nicks effort than one by Fleetwood Mac. I think his ego is just big enough that if he didn't have a grasp of production and much of the songwriting, he wouldn't have been aboard.  That's not to say he's not a great musician; I only suggest that this project suffered because it was so dominated from all aspects by him.<br />I believe that in time the first half of this disc will grow on me, and I will probably enjoy it more than I am now.  However, having listened to it four or five times already, I am still leaning towards my first impression.  The first impression is almost everything when it comes to reviewing, and at this point - after five or six listens - I find \\"Say You Will\\" a mixed bag.  On a grade scale, I would give a D+ to tracks 1 through 6, and an A- to the remainder.<br />Overall, this is worthy of three stars.  Die-hard fans of Lindsay Buckingham (in particular) and Fleetwood Mac will likely enjoy this immensely.  The casual fan or those just discovering the band will probably have a more difficult time enjoying this one.
B000069CWE|4.0|Ordinarily, I dont even bother buying remixes of songs, thinking that if the artist counldnt get it right the first time, then why try to recycle garbage, or if the song was already great, then why destroy its integrity with some inferior recreation.  But this album was a great album, even though it seems to be an attempt to recreate classics, much like rappers today take songs from the 70's and try to resale them as thier own.  The originals will always sound better.  All they basically did with this album is make the songs sound more hip hop or more techno.  If you like the rap/rock style of music that they sort of played with on Hybrid Theory, then this album is the one for you. But if you dont really care for rap to much then you may feel alienated from about half of the album.  New songs like <BR>High Voltage and My December are decent (well, maybe not high voltage), and the crowning jewel of the album is the &quot;Crawling&quot; remix with Arron from Staind. That is absolutly the ONLY remade songs on this album that sounds better than the original.  Some of the songs that they remade like &quot;In the end&quot; and &quot;Place for My Head&quot; they never should have even thought about tampering with.  &quot;In the End&quot; was a hlaf way decent song originally, but was destroyed the most of all others here. B00007AJGH|5.0|\\"Who Framed Roger Rabbit\\" finally came onto a DVD release (instead of that crappy 1999 release) that is teeming with extras.<br />1) The Movie<br />Based on the book \\"Who Censored Roger Rabbit\\" (which had the characters as comic strip stars instead of cartoon ones), the film has characters Eddie Valiant (Bob Hoskins) and Roger Rabbit (voice by Charles Fleischer) hoping (no pun intended) through a murder mystery. Eddie is sent out to prove Roger's sensual wife Jessica Rabbit (voiced by Kathleen Turner) is having an affair with the owner of the Acme company. Eddie succeeds and shows Roger the pictures, which makes Roger extremely sad and jealous. The day after it turns out that Mr. Acme was hit on the head with a safe (what else?) in the Acme Warehouse the night before. It also turns out that Roger was at the Acme Warehouse around the same time! All fingers point to Roger, as he must be the one who did it because he was jealous about Mr. Acme's \\"supposed\\" fling with Jessica. The evil and supicious Judge Doom (Christopher Lloyd) wants Roger for the murder...now. He has plans to excute him a new fashion that is being used to kill toons, Dip (which turns out is made of the same elements to clean animation cels in the commentary). Roger soon turns up at Eddie's office for help. Eddie, extremely reluctant at first, starts to grow a friendship with Roger. It comes to an hilarious end in this wonderful movie, and it is the only film to find Mickey Mouse and Bugs Bunny in one scene...together...talking to each other!<br />2) The Extras<br />There are two discs: Family-Friendly and For the Enthusiast. Don't worry, the movie is on both discs. <br />The family-friendly disc has sparse features, though. It also is very easy to navigate, and this disc doesn't have a director's commentary. Basically this disc was made so even a 5 year-old could get to the movie by himself. <br />The extras on the family-friendly disc are 3 Roger Rabbit shorts, a breif 10-minute kid-friendly \\"Who Made Roger Rabbit\\", hosted by Roger himself, Charles Fleischer, and a \\"Trouble In Toontown\\" game.<br />The 3 Roger Rabbit shorts are the only reason (except for the hidden original theatrical trailer. Hint: Push down on the main menu) to pop in the disc if you're a film enthusiast and/or a Roger Rabbit fan. They all feature the same basic story: In a Maroon Cartoon, Roger has to take care of Baby Herman and ends up in wild fashion. The real treat of each of these are the endings. Shown with Disney films through 1993, the shorts are extremely well thought out, clever, and hilarious with a personal touch by Mr. Spielburg himslef. The shorts are as of follows:<br />*Tummy Trouble (1989, released with \\"Honey, I Shrunk the Kids\\") is the first animated short to be released by Disney since 1961. It was also the most expensive animated short at that time. It features Roger trying to help Baby Herman when he swallows a baby rattle. Wouldn't you know that a Roger Rabbit short helped the \\"Honey, I\\" franchise to get popular. Many Roger fans flocked to it to see the short, yet they were also pleasantly suprised to see what followed. (NOTE: Freeze-frame the part where Roger and Baby Herman are falling through the hospital floors, and they reach a bathroom. Mickey Mouse is inside one of the stalls)<br />*Roller Coaster Rabbit (1990, shown with \\"Dick Tracy\\") immediately followed, also helping \\"Dick Tracy\\" get a decent run in the box office. It features Roger and Baby Herman trying to chase a red balloon, and yes, as the title suggest, ends on a wild roller coaster ride. Did you know that Spielburg wanted this short to preceed \\"Arachnaphobia\\"?<br />*Trail Mix-Up (1993, shown with \\"A Far Off Place\\") was a big suprise to many Roger fans, as a short (this is also the last short) had not been produced and released in almost three years. It is also the first cartoon short to use computer animation, and it shows. This is defintely the best looking of the shorts, with excellent effects to keep you watching and laughing. It features Roger trying to chase Baby Herman through the forest, leading to a Splash Mountain-esque ride through a saw mill. <br />The only bad thing about the shorts is that they don't come with commentary.<br />Now, onto the \\"For the Enthusiast\\" disc, this IS the disc for film buffs. A little hard to navigate (they could've sharpened up the menu a bit), but wonderfully done. This disc features both the movie and the commentary, along with a slew of extras.<br />The commentary is great, with Robert Zemickis and others who pitched in with the film. They offer great trivia, such as the fact that Judge Doom used to be the one who shot Bambi's mother!<br />Other extras are a \\"Before and After\\" featurette, having Bob Hoskins going through Toontown...with both the final product and the original shot product with blue-screens simutaneously. Another is \\"On-Set!\\", a look at the Benny the Cab scenes before the animation. Another has puppet figures as stand-ins for the toons. <br />\\"Toontown Confindental\\" is a trivia opition that allows you to have continous trivia along with the film. \\"Behind the Ears: The Making of Who Framed Roger Rabbit\\" is an excellent 36-minute documentary that you really just need to take the time and sit for. <br />\\"The Pig-Head Sequence\\", a deleted scene is feature also here. It has Eddie snooping through Jessica's office, and Judge Doom finds out. To get back, the Judge has his weasels throw Eddie into Toontown. Eddie comes back with an animated pig head on his face. At his office, Eddie uses turpintine to get the pig head off. Now you know why Eddie wasn't wearing a shirt when Jessica came to greet him in the final film.<br />\\"Valiant Files\\" combines image gallerys with a snoop-feature. You can look through Eddie's office for images, or just use the cheat sheet if you're lazy. This has some great images and drawings, a must-see.<br />Well, that's pretty much the DVD in my words. A wonderful buy for all. The film has themes and language that a 10-12 year old could pick up and not be suitable for, but anyone with an age lower than that would not catch it. You'll be on your couch for hours, as my title says, watching this DVD...

B00004XONN|5.0|the world is full of people who like realistic paintings, definable moments, and predetermined experiences. well, this record is not for those people. i am happier for having music new to this world that pulls apart human paradigms and reinvents. not since i stood before a kandinsky painting in paris have i felt such a profound, lovely, and confused sensation. B00004XOWM|3.0|As it's been said time and time again, this is Limp Bizkit's weakest album yet.  No question, Three Dollar Bill Y'all was their best blend of lyrics and metal music.  With Significant other, their lyrics stayed reasonably amiable; while their sound slowly faded.  And with this oddly-titled release, Limp Bizkit lost their edge and their greatness; as they've fallen victim to that sad, MTV-teen crowd.  There are a number of highlights within Chocolate Starfish, but many of the tracks are too similar and, seemingly, far-fetched cries for rap respect.  With that being said, I will (moreover) say I am still a Limp Bizkit fan.  Here's an (opinionated) overview of the 15 tracks:<br />1. Intro - ?/5 - obviously the name speaks for itself. But the take-off of Nine Inch Nails' \\"Closer\\" and \\"The Perfect Drug\\" were both ill-advised, and, pathetic.  The lyrics (minus the chorus) are rather funny; seeing as how they use the word `fxck' over 50 times.  The edited version might be twice as funny.<br />3. My Generation - 4/5 - there's good reason this song was a single, but it's too much rap.  I like the lyrics (for the most part), and the guitar sound is probably the best heard on the CD.  But the song becomes a little annoying towards the end.<br />4. Full Nelson - 2/5 - some people like this one, others don't.  I'm one of the people who doesn't. People who drive in their cars listening to \\"Rollin'\\" probably don't even realize this track is better.  There are some good/humorous quotes within; including would-be girlfriend Christina Aguilera, `Fight Club', and Ben Stiller.  It's hard to say this song is the album's best, but it's very enjoyable.<br />8. The One - 1.5/5 - a very bizarre start and weak lyrics allow for this track to be one of the worst on the album.  It's a bad attempt at an extension of \\"Re-Arranged\\".<br />9. Getcha Groove On - 3/5 - wow... Xzbit's rapping makes Fred's look like garbage.  It's not that bad, but this is not Limp Bizkit's best sound.  The background music and lyrics make it somewhat enjoyable in the end.<br />10. Take A Look Around - 5/5 - although this is certainly the finest track on the record, it doesn't fit with the rest of the music.  And that's because it's from the `Mission: Impossible 2' soundtrack.  There's no question it's the best song, but it doesn't even belong here.<br />11. It'll Be OK - 1.5/5 - read what I wrote for \\"The One\\" and assume it's also for this one.<br />12. Boiler - 2/5 - I really can't understand why this song was a `single'.  There is (again) really nothing special with it.  The words could be considered smart, but the sound doesn't flow with them in a way that's at all pleasing.<br />13. Hold On - 2/5 - I have no idea why Scott Weiland decided to sing on this song.  His voice is good, but I though this was a Limp Bizkit album.  Who knows anymore?...<br />14. Rollin' (Urban Assault Vehicle) - 2.5/5 - as I've said before, this version isn't as good as the `Air Raid' mix is.  The background sounds just like \\"Getcha Groove On\\" and/or \\"N 2 Gether Now\\".  And Fred again sounds dumb nextto DMX, Redman and Method man.<br />15. Outro - ?/5 - read what I wrote for \\"Intro\\".  Dido.<br />Although Limp Bizkit gained a few million fans with this release, they certainly lost a few.  They haven't quite lost me yet, but I have definitely lost interest.  I have a hard time seeing Limp Bizkit going back to the first-rate sound that is Three Dollar Bill Y'all.  There are no songs on this album like \\"Counterfeit\\", \\"Faith\\", or even \\"Break Stuff\\".  Nevertheless it is still an enjoyable CD to listen to.  There are a few 5-star tracks (i.e. \\"Livin' It Up\\" and \\"Take A Look Around\\"), but they don't clash well with all the bad songs.  You may enjoy this album for a few weeks or maybe a month, but over time its importance will fade.  If you want flawed rap music, buy this.  If you want good guitar sound mixed with [some good] rap, then get Three Dollar Bill Y'all instead.t to DMX, Redman and Method man.<br />15. Outro - ?/5 - read what I wrote for \\"Intro\\".  Dido.<br />Although Limp Bizkit gained a few million fans with this release, they certainly lost a few.  They haven't quite lost me yet, but I have definitely lost interest.  I have a hard time seeing Limp Bizkit going back to the first-rate sound that is Three Dollar Bill Y'all. You may enjoy this album for a few weeks or maybe a month, but over time its importance will fade.  If you want flawed rap music, buy this.  If you want good guitar sound mixed with [some good] rap, then get Three Dollar Bill Y'all instead.

She starts off with the fateful day she decided to take a shortcut through the cornfield, to the time she finds herself streaking up to heaven where she keeps her watch over her family. From up there, Susie proceeds to tell the lives of her family after her death and how each member coped in their own different way. She tells of emotions and feelings experienced and people's thoughts as she hears them. Heaven according to Sebold, differs for each person. It is not a large communal place, but rather individual compartments where each soul can \\"decorate\\" it to their wishes.<BR>As you read this book, you can hear Susie's ghostly voice, thats sorrow ridden, telling the tale. You can hear the regret in the words and the sadness of a child who will never get to grow up, but will remain trapped in the body of a 14 year old, never going forward nor backwards.<BR>In some ways this is not a book for all due to the fact that it deals with death and the afterlife with every turn of the page. But it is a sad, haunting tale that moves you. <BR>Despite some of the negative reviews on this site, you should pick the book up and flip through it to see a sample. B00003JRCQ|4.0|\\"Persuasion\\" is not as flashy as the some of the other Jane Austen stories that have been made into movies, but it is so rich and fulfilling to watch that it ranks up there with the best.  It is a definite must-have to round-out your Austen collection--not a waste of money by a long shot.<br />The overall mood of the film is hushed and a little brooding, but not boring in the least.  A caveat--any Austen fan will certainly endure, but non-Austen companions may not have the patience.  Try having a Jane Austen party with your most refined friends, as this one may not fly with a wood-chopping, motorcycle riding husband or boyfriend.<br />The camera angles and lighting are reminiscient of other British productions, markedly different from \\"American-made\\" films. For instance, the rooms are not always well-lit, but this is more realistic to the era of candle-lighting and actually enhances the viewers understanding of the setting.  As well, the camera techniques appear a little distracting to the average viewer, such as remaining fixed upon the actors' faces a little longer than \\"American\\" films and, but this is useful because it helps the viewer to feel what the characters are feeling.  I'd have to say that this film is shot in a method that is somewhere between a stage-play and a typical movie. <br />The costumes and settings are authentic and believable.  Every attention has been paid to period details and never does one think that it is all a hoax, I promise.  Nothing is worse than seeing a telephone pole in the background or asphalt roads when you're enjoying a period film!<br />Amanda Root, who plays the main character of Anne Elliot, is an excellent actress and is very convincing as the broken-hearted spinster whose undeserving family cruelly mistreats her. She has a unique brand of beauty and elegance and pulls off her performance impeccably. <br />As the story unfolds it seems that Anne is destined to live a lonely life forever, until someone from her past unexpectedly enters the picture.......there are some surprises, but ultimately a satisfying, semi-vengeful ending.  This one makes you think a little more about some of the cruelties of old English noble life and makes you appreciate the freedom to make our own choices in matters of love.

0688163173|5.0|Readers approach an established author with expectations. Not that there's anything wrong with that. Those expectations help keep readers familiar with the author, while recommending the author to friends and attending book signings --- all of those good things. So what does one do when a favorite author not only steps away from established characters, but also takes a familiar genre... and tinkers with it a bit, and thus transforms it into something else?<br />This is precisely what Dennis Lehane does with SHUTTER ISLAND, a book very different from what he has done in the past and also different from what others laboring mightily in the mystery and suspense idiom have done. Lehane made his bones with five novels featuring the duo of Patrick Kenzie and Angela Gennaro. His last novel, MYSTIC RIVER, was a departure from those characters but still covered the same territory that Lehane has demonstrated an intimate familiarity with, that being modern-day, working class Boston, through the prism of the detective novel. SHUTTER ISLAND is a totally different animal.<br />SHUTTER ISLAND takes place not in 2003 but in 1954 and not in Boston but in view of it --- in Ashecliffe Hospital --- located on Shutter Island, an island with a history dating back to the Civil War. The tale is told through the eyes of U.S. Marshal Teddy Daniels, the son of a fisherman, a man whose life has been marked by tragic violence and sorrow suffered in quiet silence. When we meet Daniels, he is on his way to Ashecliffe Hospital to investigate the disappearance of Rachel Solando, one of the patients. Her disappearance is significant because Ashecliffe is not an ordinary hospital, but a treatment and holding center for the criminally insane. The island is accessible only by ferry and there is simply nowhere that Solando could have gone.<br />However, as Daniels and Chuck Aule, his newly acquired partner, begin their investigation, it is immediately apparent that all is not right. The doctors who run the hospital are not entirely cooperative, the assistant warden seems to be more obstructive than not and the warden is an enigmatic character who, within the brief period in which the reader makes his acquaintance, is quite frightening. But to say that nothing or no one on SHUTTER ISLAND is as it or they seem to be is an understatement. And when Solando reappears as suddenly as she vanished, it is a signal that the mystery is only beginning. But SHUTTER ISLAND is more, far more, than a mystery novel. The last chapter of this book will cause you to read it again and again, and then reread the entire novel. All is revealed, yet all remains obscure.<br />SHUTTER ISLAND is a genre-bending novel that is as absorbing a book as you are likely to read this year, combining the best elements of Agatha Christie, Eric Ambler, Philip K. Dick and Dennis Lehane. Readers will be discussing this novel --- and its ultimate revelation --- for quite some time. Very highly recommended.<br />  --- Reviewed by Joe Hartlaubthe hospital are not entirely cooperative, the assistant warden seems to be more obstructive than not and the warden is an enigmatic character who, within the brief period in which the reader makes his acquaintance, is quite frightening. But to say that nothing or no one on SHUTTER ISLAND is as it or they seem to be is an understatement. And when Solando reappears as suddenly as she vanished, it is a signal that the mystery is only beginning. But SHUTTER ISLAND is more, far more, than a mystery novel. The last chapter of this book will cause you to read it again and again, and then reread the entire novel. All is revealed, yet all remains obscure.<br />SHUTTER ISLAND is a genre-bending novel that is as absorbing a book as you are likely to read this year, combining the best elements of Agatha Christie, Eric Ambler, Philip K. Dick and Dennis Lehane. Readers will be discussing this novel --- and its ultimate revelation --- for quite some time. Very highly recommended.<br />   --- Reviewed by Joe Hartlaub

B000058T5E|5.0|Jeff Beck's hammering, dive-bomber solos are still among the best in rock. The best examples of this are 'Earthquake' and 'Dirty Mind.' 'Roy's Toy,' the album's groove oriented dance track, also features a noteworthy solo and a riff to match.<br />He creates an emotional and beautiful image in 'Nadia'. The song possesses a sensual legato technique and a melody that will make you melt in ecstasy. The emotion he portrays in his playing will bring you out of your body, and Beck seems to really put a lot of himself into You Had It Coming, and 'Nadia' especially. No track is emotionless here.<br />This is not only Beck's most daring album in a career delineated by ground-breaking releases, it also contains some of his best playing yet. If Beck decides to take another long sabbatical, You Had It Coming has given fans further proof that Jeff Beck is always worth the wait.

B00006LPK5|3.0|I wish we could still go to the movies and watch one or two &quot;B&quot; pictures before seeing the main feature. Going to the cinema would be a lot more enjoyable then. It would also mean that movies like REIGN OF FIRE would get a fair shake.<br />REIGN OF FIRE is an extended &quot;B&quot; picture. Pure and simple. The movie isn't a superdriven &quot;A&quot; film intended to bring in lots and lots of cash (though that would have been nice). No, the picture was made as a throwback to the types of action shorts that used to be shown before the main picture. However, instead of swashbucklers, pirates, and Flash Gordon; we are presented with the tail of dragonslayers living in a world after nuclear destruction where dragons rule the Earth.<br />Sure the plot is thin, the dialogue cheesy, and the scenery corny. That's what B pictures look like. If you don't believe that, watch the film and play close attention. This is best illustrated in one of my favorite scenes in the movie. The two leaders of a band of humans living in rural England not too far from London entertain the children of the castle by acting out a story. The story they act out is from STAR WARS. STAR WARS! Get it? The movie is filled with such whimsical devices and if one pays attention to them, one gains an appreciation for what REIGN OF FIRE truly is:  a modern day &quot;B&quot; picture; a movie great for watching before an &quot;A&quot; picture such as RAIDERS OF THE LOST ARK. However, if nothing else, the movie is worth watching for the dragons. True they are few and far between, but they are lifelike and rather menacing.

B00000JGEI|5.0|Most sequels are imperfect remakes of the originals that they were based upon. However, (and not including trilogies), once in awhile a sequel is made that is worthy of its predecessor. TERMINATOR 2: JUDGMENT DAY is such a movie.<br />The original movie is a great piece of science fiction action cinema. T2 follows the story about a decade where the original ended. The original Terminator, the T-800, that Skynet had first sent back into time had failed to eliminate Sarah Connor before her son was born. However, a backup plan had already been thought of and the massive computer sent another Terminator, the T-1000 (an experimental model) further ahead into time to terminate John Connor before he reached maturity. However, the human resistance had their game on and sent another protector back in time, too. This time a Terminator would be a guardian.<br />Over a decade since it's original theatrical release, it is amazing how fresh and current T2 looks and feels. The action is intense, the special effects are state of the art, and the acting quite believable. The movie is full of allegorical allusions and subtle visuals that speak volumes. For example, as my brother pointed out, it's kind of frightening that T2 warns about machines taking over the world, yet we live in a society where many are totally dependent upon machines to do their bidding for them. Have machines already taken over and we just don't realize it? Not many sci-fi action pictures can make a person think that deeply.
0375758992|5.0|'An African Childhood&quot; is a searing, soulful look at an extraordinary childhood. When I first approached this book, I hesitated. My boook club was reading it and I had considered skipping that night. However, the blurbs on the inside convinced me to give it a try.<BR>I am so glad that I did. I read it in one sitting. Fuller's book haunted me. Her description of the imperialistic and racist attitudes of her parents was deeply frightening to me as the book took place in the 1970's and the 1980's. Yes we all know of British colonial attitudes in India and the Raj and the like-but that seemed so far away, so pre-World War II. In this book, you realize that such attitudes are barely a decade away.<BR>In addition, Fuller made you feel the landscape of Africa. I couldn't live there-I doubt that I would have survived a year of her childhood. Yet as she writes and writes about the aching beauty of the land, you realize that for some people, no other continent will ever suffice.

Sad really.  Linkin Park are ok at what they do, writing angst pop songs.  No matter what anyone says, Linkin Park makes pop music, verse-chorus-verse style.  I have no problem with that, all my favorite bands do the same.  Linkin just need to either rethink their lyrical perspective, or write better lyrics.  The amount of deja-vu present in these songs is way too evident to ignore.  One can't listen to Somewhere I Belong without thinking of In the End.  But as with their first cd, the hooks are here.  Especially the choruses which exhibit some nice loud in-key screaming by Chester.  This album is different in a few ways though, first of all the angst level, while it is high, it isn't so blatantly off-the-charts like Hybrid Theory's angst-du-jour &quot;One Step Closer&quot; with its SHUT UP bridge.  Which still makes me laugh.  It seems more mellow, which suits them...  The thing is, they intrigue me, they seem handcuffed by their fans, well at least to me.  They seem to be happy writing their own brand of pop, nothing wrong with it.  I just hope they go off the track with the next one, I want to see what they sound like when they aren't mad.
B000002LKF|5.0|Like seemingly half the world, I fell in love with \\"Graceland\\" upon its release in 1986.  I wore out the cassette of that album and then heard that Paul was traveling to South America for his next project.  Would it be as amazing and groundbreaking as his previous record?  \\"The Rhythm of the Saints\\" didn't set the world on fire like its predecessor, but I believe it just might be more amazing than \\"Graceland.\\"  There are other reviewers of this album who seemingly agree with me.  That assessment is not meant to take anything away from \\"Graceland,\\" which was a deserved smash.  It's just that I find myself listening almost exclusively to this album many years later.  This album seems like a precursor to the amazing bossa nova revival of today (Bebel Gilberto and the rest of the amazing Six Degrees Records artists).  I think it's the fact that Brazilian percussion moves me like nothing else on this planet.  This percussion sounds even more amazing when combined with lyrical genius of Paul Simon.  \\"Can't Run But\\" is probably the best hybrid of lyrics and percussion (that ascending melody!!!!!), but the album is uniformly strong with no misstep anywhere.  Put on the headphones and get ready for a lifetime of listening enjoyment that has sadly already been forgotten about by most music fans.  Oh well, it's their loss!

B00008J4P5|5.0|I haven't written a review on here in a while, perhaps because there haven't been an overwhelming amount of things to get excited over. A lot of people hail the whole &quot;garage rock&quot; thing, or whatever other tag line is being applied to it, as the latest deal, and I think a lot of it is good, but let's be realistic the Strokes are pretty overrated. At first listen i didn't &quot;get it&quot; right away, having been a huge fan of White Blood Cells, I listened to it more and more and then it just all broke through in my mind. Its simple FUN, straightforward, HONEST ROCK N'ROLL, that doesn't require you to sit and brood and be alone with the record. Tap your toe, sing the choruses, hum the &quot;bass line&quot; in Seven Nation Army. This is music you can enjoy wholeheartedly, and not have to feel you are somehow lesser cool for liking them. Of course you will have your rock critic snobs, who will have a variety of angles, but really this album is watertight. I don't see how it could be anything but a five star album. When you listen to the album, just listen. Don't think or worry about what it means, just sit down with it for a little while and if somehow you don't like this album, you should check your pulse and pupil dilation because you're probably not breathing. Oh yeh, and don't get hung up on the whole red and white gig that Jack and Meg White have going, they are just having fun, which is the whole point. FUN.

B000000W8C|3.0|You can't listen to \\"A Northern Soul\\" without comparing it to The Verve's stunning 1993 offering, [[ASIN:B000000WJK A Storm in Heaven]], or, for that matter, with [[ASIN:B000000WF0 Urban Hymns]] from 1997. While \\"A Northern Soul\\" does contain the same windy, psychadelic vibe of its predecessor and succeeding album in spots, the sound is not quite as special. \\"A New Decade\\" and \\"This is Music,\\" two triumphant, blustery songs lead off \\"A Northern Soul,\\" and things look promising. The following ballad, \\"On Your Own,\\" is nice enough, and leans toward the elegant style of some of the songs on \\"Urban Hymn.\\" Still, it lacks something. \\"A Northern Soul\\" misses the originality of \\"A Storm in Heaven,\\" and doesn't reach the tuneful, ambitious heights of the last Verve CD. The songs are a little plainer on \\"A Northern Soul\\", not quite as grabbing.<br /><br />Nonetheless, the guitar work by Nick McCabe on this album is pretty impressive. Like the songs on \\"A Storm in Heaven,\\" there's a huge, atmospheric swell of guitars all over the place. And when \\"A Northern Soul\\" rocks out, it's probably the rawest guitar record The Verve ever made in their unfortunately too-short career. Feelings of severe loneliness pervade the lyrics of these songs, while the music goes back and forth from a big rock sound to a slower, more muddled slew of tracks that don't really stand out toward the end of the CD.<br /><br />\\"A Northern Soul\\" hits a good stride midway through, however. The album's title track is Verve psychadelia at its finest, as is the purposely over-the-top and perfectly named \\"Brainstorm Interlude,\\" with its indecipherable lyrics, funky beat and wayward sound. Unfortunately, though, the back half of the record falters a bit: Songs like \\"Drive You Home,\\" \\"History\\" and \\"Life's an Ocean\\" are pleasant enough, but also a tad boring. I prefer the big guitar sound of the great \\"No Knock on My Door,\\" but that's just my preference.<br /><br />It should be noted that these guys owe a debt to the Smashing Pumpkins on their last tune (interlude), which is a guitar-drenched jam highly reminiscent of the Pumpkins' 1992 work on the song \\"Drown\\" from the [[ASIN:B0000028MA Singles: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack]]. The wailing guitar by McCabe may not be quite as fierce as what Billy Corgan did back then, but the mesmerizing drum and bass featured in each song have very similar sounds. The whole vibe between the two great songs is similar in style, and there's nothing wrong with that. As the Pumpkins probably owe a debt to Jimmy Hendrix for what they did on \\"Drown,\\" the Verve can thank the Pumpkins for helping pave the way for gloriously guitar-drenched tunes.<br /><br />Even when The Verve hit a somewhat average-sounding snag in their songwriting process, the band still tops most bands that are out there. The Verve's ability to use the studio as another instrument to further the depth of their unique sound is admirable; most bands don't bother to experiment so much. Overall, this is a sprawling record that takes several spins to appreciate. Think of The Verve as a psychadelic Oasis with a little more soul.s on their last tune (interlude), which is a guitar-drenched jam highly reminiscent of the Pumpkins' 1992 work on the song \\"Drown\\" from the [[ASIN:B0000028MA Singles: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack]]. The wailing guitar by McCabe may not be quite as fierce as what Billy Corgan did back then, but the mesmerizing drum and bass featured in each song have very similar sounds. The whole vibe between the two great songs is similar in style, and there's nothing wrong with that. As the Pumpkins probably owe a debt to Jimmy Hendrix for what they did on \\"Drown,\\" the Verve can thank the Pumpkins for helping pave the way for gloriously guitar-drenched tunes.       Even when The Verve hit a somewhat average-sounding snag in their songwriting process, the band still tops most bands that are out there. The Verve's ability to use the studio as another instrument to further the depth of their unique sound is admirable; most bands don't bother to experiment so much. Overall, this is a sprawling record that takes several spins to appreciate. Think of The Verve as a psychadelic Oasis with a little more soul.

B000002HEP|5.0|After purchasing \\"Blues for the Red Sun\\", Kyuss' second album, they have been without question my favorite band of all time. While Kyuss was never a very radio-friendly band, their work is simply unmatched. If you listen to a Kyuss album and are searching for that catchy hook that your typical radio band has, forget it. Kyuss' music is all about feeling and emotion. It's not music that you can just throw in your CD player while you are busy doing other things. Kyuss needs to be appreciated and taken in. If you wish to fully experience Kyuss, sit in a dark room with your headphones on, close your eyes, and be blown away. Although the music carries the stoner rock label and does have a psycadelic feel, you don't need any kind of a buzz to enjoy Kyuss. The MUSIC is the drug. \\"Welcome to Sky Valley\\" is an absolutely excellent piece of work. However, it's only a fraction of the Kyuss experience. I don't recommend buying \\"Welcome to Sky Valley.\\" I recommend buying EVERY album this band has recorded. Although I enjoy their first record, \\"Wretch\\", it truthfully comes nowhere near their later work. It's really cool to see the band progress and mature musically with each record. I was crushed when this band broke up and my only hope is that someday they join forces again to create the best music ever made.

B000069KGM|5.0|&quot;Chicago Transit Authority&quot; is an amazing achievement for the group Chicago for many reasons. When it was recorded in 1968, the group was given two weeks to lay down all of the tracks. For four album sides worth of material!<BR>The performances, considering the pressure they must have been under in their first studio experience are just astounding.<BR>And of course there is the music, which when it emerged in 1969 was like nothing else before it; and nothing like it came after.  Radio staples like &quot;Does Anybody Really Know What Time It Is?&quot; and &quot;Beginnings&quot; still sound great because the music just doesn't fit any &quot;category&quot;. It's pop; it's rock; a little jazzy; terrific melodies and great vocal harmonies; lots of feel. <BR>The CD opener, &quot;Introduction&quot;, is a perfect showcase for the band and a preview what lies ahead on the rest of the tracks. Great horns, terrific drumming by Danny Seraphine, and Terry Kath's unique blues-rock guitar.<BR>Kath goes on to dominate this recording, with solos on almost every tune and long jam stretches highlighting his improvising skills. Instrumentals &quot;Poem 58&quot; and &quot;Liberation&quot; remain classics in this vein, while &quot;Listen&quot;, &quot;I'm a Man&quot; and &quot;South California Purples&quot; are bluesy songs with some great Kath guitar placed within. <BR>The dominance of Terry Kath on this album is my only criticism. For the record, I am NOT criticisng Terry's playing. I dig every note.  But,although many call this the &quot;greatest&quot; Chicago record because it has the most edge, since it does not find the group really branching out in different directions yet and highlighting each and every members' talents like on Chicago II or VII, it is really not the best document of this truly eclectic band.<BR>I hate to admit it, but &quot;Free Form Guitar&quot; which, if it had been a minute long or so would have been fine, but I've been skipping past this track for years as it's just tedious.<BR>A true high point which shows Chicago at it's best with vocalists Robert Lamm and Peter Cetera sharing the lead duties and the horns really blowing is &quot;Someday&quot;.  Political rumblings aside, this is just a great tune. <BR>Although this record finds producer James William Guercio still experimenting with mixing (the horns are put to one side), the overall sound is very live, which adds to the timelessness of this disc.  <BR>&quot;Chicago Transit Authority&quot; burst onto the music scene after Blood Sweat and Tears had released a couple of recordings and other &quot;one hit wonders&quot; such as the Buckinghams were using horns in a popular format, but anyone listening to Chicago's first release knew that this was something really new and innovative.<BR>BS&amp;T were great, but they were bascially a jazz band mixing in some pop angles.  Chicago was a true rock band, with a top notch guitarist, three great vocalists and a really unique horn section with it's own personality, feel and sound. And of course, the songwriting: cutting-edge, high quality and truly fresh.   <BR>After &quot;Chicago Transit Authority&quot;, Chicago left all &quot;horn rock&quot; bands in the dust, and for obvious reasons.<BR>This is a &quot;must have&quot; disc for anyone interested in Chicago, or, seeking out all important early rock recordings.
B000059QY2|5.0|Rigoletto is one of my absolute favorite operas, and this DVD version made it even better!<br />The cast is perfect, at least when it comes to singing, but I just can't stop LAUGHING at Edita Gruberova's infernal gestures and behaviour... Wixell is just as good as an actor as a singer, and I don't think Pavarotti acts too bad either. But anyway, you forget his bad acting when you can hear him sing!
B000069KE0|5.0|Their first album &quot;Chicago Transit Authority&quot;, may have put them on the musical map, but Chicago's second album shows this legendary band defining their rock-jazz style.  &quot;CTA&quot; was a groundbreaker in so many ways: Terry Kath's dominant hard rock guitar work,  the blazing horns weaving into the mix of each song in a way that had never been heard before,  elements of rock, jazz, and R&amp;B blended so uniquely and three distinctly different and talented lead vocalists creating an electrifying listening experience. <BR>&quot;Chicago II&quot; just doesn't expand on this approach or even take it one step further, with this album, Chicago seemed to go light years into new musical ground.<BR>&quot;Movin' In&quot; opens the disc with a powerhouse Big Band style that grabs the listener and the band never let's go. Terry Kath, though less prominant than on &quot;CTA&quot; carries out some of his best guitar  work with the classic &quot;25 or 6 to 4&quot; , &quot;It better End Soon&quot; suite, and &quot;In the Country&quot;.  The &quot;Ballet for a Girl In Buchanan&quot; suite  highlights two top ten classics: &quot;Make Me Smile&quot; (more amazing solo guitar work by Kath) and &quot;Colour My World&quot; both sung by Terry with his trademark R&amp;B baritone.  Sinfully melodic songs such as &quot;Wake Up Sunshine&quot; and &quot;Fancy Colours&quot; stick to your ear long after the disc ends.  Chicago explores a bit of orchestral style with &quot;AM/PM Mourning&quot; with intense strings and some Big band ballad textures.<BR>The CD closes with Peter Cetera's first written song for Chicago &quot;Where Do We Go From Here?&quot;.  A simple tune in style and arrangement that foreshadows Peter's incredibly melodic writing contributions to this amazing band for years to come.   <BR>In a nutshell, the horn and vocal arrangements on this CD display Chicago at their best and the songwriting is incredibly strong and diverse. <BR>If you are looking to explore the eclectic musical catalogue that Chicago has amassed over several decades, this is the CD is a must as it evidences their defining moment.
B00008H2LE|5.0|To me, Meteora is a great follow-up to Hybrid Theory. (Unlike Reanimation, which was way too out there) This album shows the real Linkin Park by using lots of different types of music. This is on of the most unique songs on the album, and also one of the best.<br />08 Figure .09 8/10- Typical Linkin Park song, sounds a lot like their old stuff.<br />09 Breaking The Habit 8/10- This electronica song is new for Linkin Park. At first, I would ignore this song since I was looking more for guitar riffs but after awhile I started to like it. It has a great vocals from Chester.<br />10 From The Inside 10/10- This has good guitar riffs and great lyrics. A great song from Linkin Park.<br />11 Nobody's Listening 9/10- A complete hip hop song, another new thing from Linkin Park. (Excluding Reanimation) It has really great chorus and lyrics, I especially like the guitar riffs during the chorus.<br />12 Session 5/10- This song sounds a lot like A Cure For The Itch, which was a song I didn't like. I personally dont like this song since hip hop intrumentals aren't my thing.<br />13 Numb 9/10- A great song to end the album, just like Pushing Me Away was for Hybrid Theory.
B00003CXXP|2.0|One thing I would like to comment on, is the fact that this film was touted as being the project that Stanley Kubrick wanted to make before his death. And after watching AI, I would safely say that with Speilberg it turned out to be less 2001 and more ET and Pinnochio,less thought provoking masterpiece as I suspect it would have turned out to be from a genuis like Kubrick, and more sentimental dribble that a very talented director like Speilberg finds himself trapped in lately.<BR>Is Speilberg overrated? I don't think so, for films like  Duel,Jaws and Colour Purple(in my opinion his best film to date and a cinematic masterpiece) demonstrates a very able and talented artist, yet he seems to have lost it lately. <BR>Haley Joel Osment as the robot kid with human emotions is one of the best child actors around today, and delivers his role flawlessly. Jude Law is also one of the best Brit exports today, an actor with immense capabilites..Yet what I have problems with is the script which seems to be lost between sentimentality and epic scale science fiction. The marriage of these two is very delicate and the right balance should have been found, given the subject matter, which alas was not found here.<BR>Speilberg's direction seems uneven, the first half being the more coherent, the second a bit lost.<BR>Yet the DVD itself is of top quality and full of extras to satisfy any digital afficiando.<BR>A disappointing film on all counts, and a lost opportunity to film and understand Kubrick's vision, by a director that I know can make much better movies, if only he sheds the excessive sentimentality that has become a staple of his moveimaking of late.

B000008H24|5.0|I definitely agree with the spotlight reviewer on why so many Tull fans hate War Child. I go one step further and state that this album is one of Tull's best.  In fact, I think it is the best Tull album post-Thick As A Brick.  It is not as brilliant as Aqualung, Stand Up, and Benefit, but it is more solid than Too Old..., Songs From the Wood, Heavy Horses, etc.  I became a Tull fan in the late 1980s, and purchased their back catalogue in the order in which I found their records, not by chronology (A Passion Play being the last I bought).  I, therefore, had no expectations when I put on War Child.  I liked it when I first heard it and, unlike other albums, I like it more today than then.  It has a folk sound, but not a woodsy sound like Songs From the Wood and Heavy Horses.  It has a folk sound that might be appropriate on a old sailing ship setting off to find riches for jolly ol' England.  It is also more solid than their later albums.  Usually Tull albums have a song or two I skip or do not enjoy very much.  I can play War Child straight through.  It is a real pleasure to listen to. The only time I cringe is<BR>                     during the last part of the otherwise soothing ballad &quot;Ladies&quot;.<br />Besides this one complaint, the rest of the tracks are amazing. The heavy use of accordion and tracks like &quot;Queen and Country&quot; and &quot;The Third Hoorah&quot; gives the album a sea expedition theme. &quot;Bungle in the Jungle,&quot; the most familiar track, may be a little too commercial but is still a fun number and probably attracted new fans (is that so terrible?). &quot;Skating Away&quot; is beautiful and so is &quot;Only Solitaire&quot; if you don't pay attention to the crude lyrics. &quot;Back-Door Angels&quot; and &quot;Sea Lion&quot; hook together to make a wonderful 9:00 theatrical number. &quot;Two Fingers&quot; is a version of &quot;Lick Your Fingers Clean&quot; which is on the boxed 20th anniversary set and is highlighted by excellent acoustic guitar. War Child is also the last album where you hear Ian Anderson's low, smooth voice. It begins to get a little higher on Minstrel in the Gallery and definitely changes by Songs From the Wood. My advice is to not listen to disgruntled Tull fans who dismiss this record as a &quot;sell out&quot;.  Besides &quot;Bungle&quot;, nothing else on this album is outwardly commercial.  &quot;Skating&quot; may be the more accessible of the other tracks but it does not sound like a sappy ploy for radio play. Grab a copy and find out for yourself.
B000088E6D|5.0|My girlfriends have raved about this Michael Bubl and his sound. I now will admit, they are right. Best songs: Come Fly With Me, Moon dance, You'll never Find, kissing a fool  - actually EVERy song on the album have become fav's.
B000002MUN|5.0|As a huge Tom Petty fan, I find the statement for this album, &quot;Tom Petty is like a Beatle immitating Bob Dylan,&quot; a huge understatement and insult to Petty's maturing music repetoire.  After all, this album did win a Grammy the year it was released.  The album is beautiful, especially with the use of a full orchestra on certain tracks.  It is naive to assume that the music of a true artist will stay stagnant through time, or that without the Heartbreakers' accompanyment, Petty will not come up with something completely original and unique from their sound.  This is my favorite Petty album produced so far.  It is absolutely flawless.

B00004X0Q0|5.0|Some bands achieve greatness with time, some get it when they first start out, and some never achieve it all. At The Drive-In achieved greatness the first time they stepped onto a stage. They fall into that very small category of bands that will kick your ... every time they come out with something, no matter how strange or weird it is. This record should have been my generation's \\"Nevermind,\\" but instead, people chose to ignore it and listen to more predictable and boring music. Even if you hate punk or even hard rock music in general, you have to hand it to ATDI for not boring you. Every song on this CD is relentless, and no matter how hard you try to get away, it pulls you in. Even the slow songs, \\"Invalid Litter Dept.\\", \\"Quarantined\\", and \\"Non-Zero Possibility\\" don't make you want to skip them over. Every song on this record is there for some purpose, some reason for life, and ATDI uses every chance they have to make the song great. The first 4 songs on the CD are just hardcore punk rock, with fast drumming, killer riffs, and everything you would ever want in a great album. \\"One Armed Scissor,\\" the song that should have brought them to stardom, is quite possibly the best song recorded in this new millenium. Some may beg to differ, but I think this album was the best thing recorded in the 00s, (QOSTA's Songs For The Deaf being second). The rest of the album includes it's climatic 6 minute epic, \\"Invalid Litter Dept.\\", along with a song with Iggy Pop!! I mean, how great is that?!?! After a killer (and I mean KILLER) opening with \\"Arcarsenal\\", they end it slowly but beautifully with the intense \\"Non-Zero Possiblity.\\" And every track in between is perfect. Seriously, you can't get any better with this CD. As you all probably know, At The Drive-In sadly broke up right before they could have been huge. Of course, after that their record label (the Beastie Boys' Grand Royal) went bust, and they all went their seperate ways. Or did they?? Jim, Tony, and Paul (guitar, bass, and drums) went and formed their own band, Sparta, which kicks major ... I must say. I've seen them twice, I know. And Cedric and Omar (lead singer and lead guitar) formed a band called The Mars Volta. This band is weird, but at the same time extremely great! It sounds a lot what ATDI might have done if they hadn't had broken up. Or maybe it's just Cedric's voice... Either way, ATDI is over, and two great bands came out of the ashes. But, neither band (even though I love them both) will never equal the greatness reached on this album (or on Acrobatic Tenement, in/CASINO/out, or Vaya) and that's OK. No band in a long time has impressed and amazed me as much as this little punk band out of El Paso, TX. Just take my advice, and buy this CD, then buy the rest of the ATDI catalog, and then go out and buy Sparta's new CD and Mars Volta's EP (new CD coming in summer)! Oh, by the way...the title of my review comes from track one on this CD!

B000059TEP|5.0|Ghost is a magical movie. The top grossing film of 1990 is also one of the best movies of the decade, no question. Here is a rare film that can be watched over and over and still make the viewer feel the same emotion every time--you wanna laugh and cry all at once. The film combines elements of almost every film genre--fantasy, ghost story, mystery, horror, romance, drama, thriller, and comedy blend together seamlessly for a touching, emotional, and suspenseful roller coaster ride.<br />Patrick Swayze and Demi Moore are fantastic and Whoopi Goldberg definitely deserves that Oscar for her hilarious supporting role as psychic Oda Mae Brown. She successfully brings a light touch to an otherwise dark and brooding film.<br />Directing his first film on his own, Jerry Zucker (who was partnered with his brother David and Jim Abrahams on the Airplane! movies and other spoofs) has done an impressive job, with considerable help from a brilliant editor, Walter Murch, and Oscar winning screenplay by Bruce Joel Rubin. <br />Rubin has crafted a well-paced and entertaining tale. He is a born storyteller, with a gift for weaving an intricate, involving narrative as well as an ability to tap into some of our deepest hopes and fears. What makes Ghost special is the way it takes what might have been an unbearably sentimental story and turns it into a powerfully romantic drama with a positive message about life, death and love. He manages to make us feel a flurry of emotions while we stare dumbfounded at the unbelievable events unfolding before us, making them extremely plausible. He sucks us into the tightly knit tale from the very first frame, and doesn't let go until the end credits begin to roll. <br />Ghost WILL make you believe.

B00008PW3Q|2.0|I have been a big fan of all of the Fleetwood Mac lineups for 30hmmm...something years. One of the good things about their repertoire is that there is an album to satisfy any mood. From the raw and bluesy era of Peter Green, the slightly more progressive sound of the Bob Welch era, the laid back beautifully blended sounds of the early introduction of Stevie and Lindsey to the painfully honed hi-tech production of the current lineup...sans Christine McVie. I own a copy of the Buckingham Nicks album which I am also very fond of and have the utmost respect for Lindsey, both as a musician and a producer. My favorite Mac album isn't &quot;Rumours&quot; like most other Fleetwood Mac fans, but &quot;Fleetwood Mac&quot;, where Lindsey's focus was on playing and songwriting before he became obsessed with crafting the perfect sound in production. Considering Lindsey's comment on &quot;The Dance&quot; regarding a solo album in progress, it's my guess that &quot;Say You Will&quot; is that very album with Stevie, Mick and John along for the ride and the Fleetwood Mac name along for the revenue. Christine's absence leaves a gaping hole in the music. Her classicly catchy, upbeat, keyboard oriented tunes are conspicuously missing from this recording. I completely understand her wanting to be out from under the weight of the band and touring but I just wish they could reach some sort of compromise to keep her influence. Perhaps she could just like, email her offerings or something. If my hunch is wrong about this being Lindsey's long awaited solo album and the band really did have an equal part in the making of it then it's my opinion that either Lindsey's really not a very good team player or the rest of the band simply hadn't much to contribute. Stevie contributed some good things and should be given her due credit but on the whole, &quot;Say You Will&quot; screams of Lindsey. I would give this a 5 star rating as a Lindsey Buckingham album, but it's not. This is Lindsey Buckinghamat his all-time best, <BR>but Fleetwood Mac...hmmm...you'd better decide for yourself.

But Let it Bleed is loose, diverse, and fun. I thought the CD layer on this disk was a big improvement over the original CD release (what wouldn't be?), but for whatever reason it was marred in spots by overmodulation distortion on the guitar -- that needles in your ears sound you get when someone pushes the meters too far into the red.  The SACD layer, by contrast, is absolutely stunning.  The only thing I can compare it to is listening to original master tapes, which I got to do now and then in a former life.

B00006JL1Z|4.0|It is no secret that the lineup with Stevie Nicks and Lindsey Buckingham was the most successful line-up in the US, and if you bought the first 'Greatest Hits' package, you got most of the big hits that most remember. If you purchased either the lengthy box set or the 2 disc set of 'The Chain,' then you got most of the hits, plus very little material from their pre-'Rumours' years. Or if you got 'The Dance,' then you got all the hits redone live. Now what the people don't think about is that this particular hits collection was a prelude to their new release, as it was touted in the TV promos and the sticker on the cover, and is suppose to be a definitive collection. This is everything but a definitive collection. From the sequencing, to the bewildering tracklist, and the feeling that you didn't get all that was deserved. <BR>     The obvious is that it does include most all of the singles that were released, with the exception of 'Fireflies,' 'The Farmer's Daughter,' 'Save Me,' 'Hard Feelings,' 'Oh Diane,' and anything released after 1990 save 'Paper Doll.' The album also excludes anything before 1975, where you miss songs like 'Hypnotized' (which has won awards for consistent airplay), and 'Black Magic Woman' (a hit for Santana). Not that all of these were big hits, but they were the best their albums had to offer. The exclusion of these singles were to make room for 'What Makes You Think You're The One,' 'Gold Dust Woman' and 'Storms,' which aren't bad songs, but don't deserve to be alongside a hits collection if they weren't pulled out of their respective albums as singles. If one thinks this is petty, imagine what the UK was subjected to. They had the most bewildering tracklist of all, having cuts from 1967-1969 along side tracks from 1975-1990, completely avoiding 1970-1974. <BR>     The addition of single mixes were nice, such as the mixes for 'Rhiannon' and 'Over My Head' but what about 'Say You Love Me,' 'Gypsy,' 'Big Love' (the latter came as a remix). Notthat they were sorely missed, but at least it would have kept consistent with what was trying to be accomplished.     Definitive? No, absolutely not. Enjoyable? Well, yes. This is a good place to start for those who want an overview of what the 'Mac Attack' is all about, but for other than casual fans, this is a wasted opportunity caused by record company greed.

B00007H1Y2|4.0|A playful instrumental collaboration between roots music avatar Ry Cooder and Cuban guitarist Manuel Galban, of the early 1960s doowop/pop/son ensemble, Los Zafiros.  It took me a while to warm to this record, but when I did I was won over... It's a fun, spirited collabration, and Cooder and Galban obviously got a real kick out of working together.  It did seem, however, like territory that's already been covered in recent years -- rock-tinged. latin-dance-y, neo-exotica, as heard in the work of bands such as The Friends Of Dean Martinez, Marc Ribot, et al. Still, Ry's a master of world pop, a trailblazer who was touching on this material decades ago, and he still has a masterful touch.  Longtime fans and devotees-by-way-of-Buena Vista alike will not be disappointed.

Marvin dedicated this album to the man who would kill him 13 years later.  <BR>This is probably the most haunting piece of music from the 20th Century, and therefore it is truly timeless. 6304416415|5.0|At theatres In the summer of '89, \\"Honey I Shrunk the kids\\" more than held it's own against box office heavyweights such as \\"Do the Right thing\\", \\"Batman\\", and \\"Indiana Jones and the last crusade\\". Quite the feat, considering it's relatively obscure cast (well, compared to the afforementioned films.) <br />The movie starts out with a nice animation sequence that looks as good now as it did 13 years ago. The live action starts as a typical Saturday morning in suburbia at the Szalinski's house, except that Wayne (Rick Moranis) is a bumbling inventor who built a shrinking ray in his attic that he can't get to work, his son (Robert Oliveri) is a mirror-image. And the daughter (Amy O'Neill) is pretty much your typical Blond teenager [a good looking one at that ;)] <BR>who hopes she gets asked to the dance. The mother, Diane Szalinski, played by Marcia Strassman (of Welcome Back, Kotter fame) does a good job as well. Cork, the family dog also deserves mentioning. <br />Next door are the All-American Thompsons, who have big plans for a weekend fishing trip. Their oldest son Russ Jr. (Thomas Wilson Brown) is less than enthusiastic about those plans. He's a bit scrawny for his age and Big Russ has expectations to see him excel at High School football, which isn't Little Russ's Niche. Meanwhile younger son Ron Thompson (Jared Rushton) is the apple of Big Russ's eye, and can be quite mischievous at times, setting up a booby trap that his dad walks into. <br />The underrated Matt Frewer steals the show as Big Russ Thompson, Brash and Sarcastic (in a good way of course). And providing the perfect compliment is his wife, the calmer Mae Thompson (played by Kristine Sutherland). <br />The backstory is this:Ron Thompson hits a baseball into the Szalinskis attic, in turn setting off the shrinking machine (which hadn't worked until that point) and in their effort to retrieve the ball, Ron and Nick get zapped and are 1/4 inch tall, Amy and Russ Jr., who walk up to the attic wondering what happened to them, meet a similar fate. Wayne returns home from a dismal day at work, having been made a laughing stock because of his lack of proof for the shrinking machine. He takes his frustration out on the machine itself, severely damaging it in the process, he sweeps the broken parts (and the four kids) off the floor and into the trash bag. He then takes it out across the yard, and the kids are, as Nick eloquently says \\"We're now a quarter of an inch tall, and sixty four feet from the house. That's an equivalent of three-point-two miles. That's a long way. Even for a man of science.\\" Even more of a trek considering the extra thick grass they must walk through. <br />En route the gang faces Swarms of bees and scorpions [among other obstacles that I won't give away;)]. There's decent use of special effects and, even if they may look a bit fake, it's still entertaining nonetheless. I'll end my description here, as anything more would spoil the film. <br />If this review doesn't entice you to check out \\"Honey, I shrunk the kids\\", I don't know what will. It's a classic in my opinion.<br />As an added bonus, the hilarious Roger Rabbit short \\"Tummy Trouble\\" is included.

B000005RQT|4.0|I already wrote a review for the standard cd version, but since it doesn't appear on my reviews list, this intenionally different one will. This is the version of this hard rock classic to own. Awesome, Spinal Tap-like volume in the red, remastered sound. The extras are nice, particularly the smokin' Black Night single on which Blackmore punishes the tremolo bar, and an interesting alternate version of Speed King. I now know of 3 official alternate versions, the other two on the must own 'Listen Learn Read On' box set. This was the first hard rock album that featured two lead soloists(both virtuosos), and there's only one guitarist for a change. How many rock bands have a keyboardist who, like the guitarist, is just as strong technically and volume-wise? Very few indeed, and remember, Purple's playing only got better from here, and was actually already better live. Perhaps Led Zeppelin were at home in the studio more often since they actually got along, but Purple Mk II did manage some incredible studio performances(and they were always better live, the best hard rockers out there)before singer Gillan had enough of Blackmore and made like a speed king out of there. Definitely lamentable considering Gillan's phenomenal vocal range(\\"Child In Time\\" on here says it all)pitted against Blackmore's in-your-face guitar heroics. Of course live, with Lord's classical and jazz leanings as well, this old album had simply more to offer all around than the competion(the closest thing in '70 was Zeppelin, but they were hard-blues rock). Anyway, this is early, raw Mk II trying on their first studio offering for size. That's the charm here, hearing hard rock's finest ever live band using volume and technical agression as a weapon, before more polished later studio albums. Machine Head is Mk II Purple's best(not counting live)I think, but this is where it all began, baby. To paraphrase a tune here, \\"Heeeaaarrr them flyyyy\\"!

B00006JLX4|5.0|As the initial foundation of the alt. rock boom that took place in the early 90s, Indie Rock has always been a lower profile counterpart to the genre that spawned success story acts like The Smashing Pumpkins or Nirvana.  Mixing catchy melodies with abrasive feedback in the same fashion as their alt. rock peers, but always willing to remain in the realm of \\"cult classics,\\" no band sums up the concept of indie rock better than the original slacker quartet of Pavement.  A true musical embodiment of the disenchanted wasteoid generation of teenage slackers who fell through the cracks of alternative rock's more mainstream ideals, Pavement captures all the anguish, frustration, boredom, and angst of any and all American teenagers and as the band's first studio album, Slanted &amp; Enchanted immediately struck a chord with the youth of America.  The blissful waves of sonic distortion and the overriding sloppy, carefree spirit of the music fully expressed the intangible sense of immediacy that fills the lives of adolescents.  In essence, the lazy drawling vocals, the twin guitars that could join in a power chord alliance or clash in manic solos in an instant, and the vague yet strangely depressing lyrics all convey a state of emotional turmoil, sometimes even all out warfare, that is a perfect representation of the world's many dissatisfied teens.  Furthermore, this constant battle of emotions not only results in a pristine representation of the ravaged teenage mind, but also gives the album an immense sense of musical diversity.  From the bouncy punk of \\"Two States\\" to the melancholy, introspection of \\"Here,\\" Slanted matches its constantly shifting moods with an equally varied assortment of styles.  Slanted and Enchanted is then finally tied together with decidedly rough production that accurately captures the group's sporadic live dynamics, delivering their multifaceted message in as pure and untainted a form as possible.  Easily one of the greatest albums of the 90s, Slanted and Enchanted's wonderfully amateurish charm, hilarious wit, and willingness to experiment makes it a dense blend of punk, alt. and even Avant Garde, that successfully revamps the musical accomplishments of past visionaries for a brand new generation of listeners.<br />While the album itself is already a significant accomplishment in the world of modern rock and is most certainly a rewarding listen, the ludicrous amount of bonus material included on the Slanted and Enchanted Luxe and Redux reissue greatly enhances the CD.  Including 2 John Peel Sessions, 2 Eps, 1 album session, and 1 entire live show, this set is enough to make any Pavement fan salivate, and with good reason.  The quality of these included B-sides, rarities, and otherwise hard to find tracks is consistently breathtaking, easily ranking with the best tracks off of Slanted, which only further shows the mind-blowing creative potency of Pavement at the beginning of their career.  If you already own Slanted and Enchanted, buy the reissue, and if you don't, then still buy the reissue because when literally 140 minutes of music and 48 tracks are put on one album, and the album never becomes dull for even a minute, you know that there is definitely some real talent behind the band.

Go out and buy it, its wortht he money.

B000002L99|5.0|This is obviously the first VH album featuring Sammy Hagar as lead singer. It was noticably different from all previous albums. Most attribute this jarring shift in the bands sound to Sammy, but it really wwasn't his doing. Listen again--it's actually Eddie that changed so drastically. There are only 9 songs; 3 are synth-driven. Of the remaining 6, only 2 are heavy guitar songs, and even those aren't the heavy-handed style we've come to adore Ed for so much.<br />Ed obviously made a decision to depart from his signature sound for the sake of branching out, I suppose. But it's poor Sammy that gets blamed for it.<br />Overall, 5150 is a fantastic album, and contrary to what another reviewer wrote, it has aged beautifully. \\"Love Walks In,\\" \\"Dreams,\\" \\"5150,\\" \\"Summer Nights,\\" \\"Best of Both...\\" And the list goes on. In and of itself, it's a wonderful album, a classic. But when held up to the Dave-era standard, it will never satisfy the die-hard old VH fan.

People keep complaining that it isn't a true fantasty, but what really defines what a fantasy is?  The writing is excellent, but comparing this book to Tolkien is futile.  For one thing, Tolkien's books were scene extravaganza's this however is more of a character extravaganza.  The sets in this are just set's for the characters say their dialogue in.  (Though some are beautifully written)<br />  Now I have to agree that it is definately a type of soap opera, but that doesn't mean it resembles any of those hokey daytime shows.  It just means that it is mainly about well drawn characters interactions with each other, and their scheming with and against each other.<br />  But the biggest weakness of this book is its lack of making the overall theme clearly implied, or understood.  I'm sorry, but to have an epic series you need to at least let the reader know for sure that there is an epic plot and theme that carries throughout the series.  You don't have to state it is, but just leaving the reader unsure and unclear if its there, is a big weakness for an epic series.<br />  And though each characters little story or theme seems to come full round by the end of this, you're left asking how does this all fit together, or does this all fit together?  I took off most for that, because I think overall story is the most important thing for an epic fantasy.  But all in all, a fascinating read.

B000062XGB|4.0|Whatever creative links truly exist we think of the 1999 film \\"Anna the King\\" as a dramatic version of \\"The King and I,\\" which was a musical version of the 1946 film \\"Anna and the King of Siam,\\" which was inspired by the diaries of Anna Leonowens.  Now, it turns out that Anna Leonowens, who was hired to tutor the children of the king of Siam in 1862, greatly embellished her adventures in her celebrated book.  She was neither a governess nor an advisor to the king, her late husband was a desk clerk and not a military officer, and she made up the lurid stories about the king throwing wives into dugeons and the public torture and burning of a consort and the monk she loved.  Of course, history rarely matters to Hollywood and in this case the idea of a romance between Anna and the King overwhelms everything else.<br />The real King Mongkut of Siam was about 60 years old when Anna arrived to teach English to the king's children (you can easily find photographs of him on the web), which would be the final blow to thoughts of romance if all those wives, concubines, public executions, and pagan believes did not turn off any widowed Englishwoman employed in his palace.  But despite its flaws \\"The King and I\\" is a pretty good romance; the scene where Yul Brynner dances with Deborah Kerr is one the sexiest scenes in Hollywood history (watch how they look at each other after the dance finishes) and there is no profit to be made in trying to convince a modern audience that this story is not a romance.  We might have a more accurate view of George Custer at the Little Bighorn, but we cling to our romanticized vision of \\"Anna and the King.\\"<br />This is a gorgeous film.  The story may well distort the cultural history of what is now Thailand, but the film can certainly inspire you to want to visit.  Yun-Fat Chow plays the King as a figure refined enough to tempt Anna, who is played by Jodie Foster.  Ironically enough, in this version of the tale, which seeks to present King Mongkut as more cultured and civilized than ever, Anna's prejudicial views stand out more than ever.  Every time she stands up to the king, ask yourself if she would really do the same thing to Queen Victoria.  She might be a woman but she is an Englishwoman, not to mention a Christian, and that pretty much settles everything.<br />Ultimately, two things distinguish this version of the story.  The first is that Anna undergoes much more of a transformation that the King this time around.  The person who benefits most from her presence is Prince Chulalongkorn (Keith Chin), heir to the thrown, and most of that education is implied rather than shown.  In fact, there are several scenes that make it clear the King is smarter than Anna; his problem is more than of pride than anything else.  In the major subplot involving Tuptim (Ling Bai), Anna only makes things worse from start to finish.  The second is that the political problems of Mongkut and his kingdom are considerably more serious.  Troops from Burma are crossing the border and killing Siamese.  This raises the possibility of war, but since Burma is under the protection of the British, the stakes are pretty high.  The end result is that more than ever before, Anna gets to be the salvation of the King and the nation of Siam (i.e., Thailand banned \\"The King and I\\" and they will ban this film too).<br />\\"Anna and the King\\" is a beautiful film, but does not touch the heart the way a true romance should.  In fact, the heart of the film is in the affection of the king for his youngest daughter, Princess Fa-Ying (Melissa Campbell), who truly touches him in a way no other person does.  Director Andy Tennant captured magic with \\"Ever After,\\" but this film ends up missing the mark.  It has Anna, the King, and even dancing, but this time around it is not enough.t as more cultured and civilized than ever, Anna's prejudicial views stand out more than ever.  Every time she stands up to the king, ask yourself if she would really do the same thing to Queen Victoria.  She might be a woman but she is an Englishwoman, not to mention a Christian, and that pretty much settles everything.<br />Ultimately, two things distinguish this version of the story.  The first is that Anna undergoes much more of a transformation that the King this time around.  The person who benefits most from her presence is Prince Chulalongkorn (Keith Chin), heir to the thrown, and most of that education is implied rather than shown.  In fact, there are several scenes that make it clear the King is smarter than Anna; his problem is more than of pride than anything else.  In the major subplot involving Tuptim (Ling Bai), Anna only makes things worse from start to finish.  The second is that the political problems of Mongkut and his kingdom are considerably more serious.  Troops from Burma are crossing the border and killing Siamese.  This raises the possibility of war, but since Burma is under the protection of the British, the stakes are pretty high.  The end result is that more than ever before, Anna gets to be the salvation of the King and the nation of Siam (i.e., Thailand banned \\"The King and I\\" and they will ban this film too).<br />\\"Anna and the King\\" is a beautiful film, but does not touch the heart the way a true romance should.  In fact, the heart of the film is in the affection of the king for his youngest daughter, Princess Fa-Ying (Melissa Campbell), who truly touches him in a way no other person does.  Director Andy Tennant captured magic with \\"Ever After,\\" but this film ends up missing the mark.  It has Anna, the King, and even dancing, but this time around it is not enough.
